user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_SHA256_update:
```c
void
MHD_SHA256_update (struct Sha256Ctx *ctx,
                   const uint8_t *data,
                   size_t length)
{
  unsigned bytes_have; /**< Number of bytes in buffer */

  mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0));

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

  /* Note: (count & (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE-1))
           equals (count % SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE) for this block size. */
  bytes_have = (unsigned) (ctx->count & (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE - 1));
  ctx->count += length;

  if (0 != bytes_have)
  {
    unsigned bytes_left = SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have;
    if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      sha256_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
  }

  while (SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)
  {   /* Process any full blocks of new data directly,
         without copying to the buffer. */
    sha256_transform (ctx->H, data);
    data += SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE;
    length -= SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE;
  }

  if (0 != length)
  {   /* Copy incomplete block of new data (if any)
         to the buffer. */
    memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have, data, length);
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
explanation: All other fragments implement the core update logic and must be preserved: the computation of bytes_have and increment of ctx->count update the context state; the conditional combining of buffered bytes (memcpy into ctx->buffer) and the call to sha256_transform are needed to produce correct block-wise processing; the while loop processing full blocks and the final memcpy of any remaining bytes to the buffer are necessary to maintain correct hash state across successive updates. Removing or altering those operations would change program behaviour (the produced hash), so they are not candidates for dead-code per Rule 2.2. The two reported fragments are candidates for investigation because (1) the assertion may be compiled out in production (so it may be effectively non-executing or no-op), and (2) the early-return guarded by MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE only short-circuits when length == 0; removing that return would not change the subsequent executed statements' effects (they handle length == 0 safely), so the early-return may be redundant/dead in some build configurations. Other lines (casts, memcpy calls, sha256_transform calls, assignments modifying ctx state and length/data pointers) have observable effects and therefore should not be treated as dead code without deeper functional evidence.
